title: Lincoln Memorial Reflecting Pool, Washington DC
address: 2 Lincoln Memorial Cir NW, Washington DC, DC 20037
review_list:
Loved the Lincoln Memorial but the Reflecting Pool was dry. Unsure why but the photos would have been much better with the pool, I'm sure.

Of all the memorials I've visited, this is the most imposing. Lincoln was and is larger than life. He doesn't look down on you, instead, he watches over you, as he did our Nation; like a protective parent. Every American should study Lincoln's life so that they can fully appreciate his memorial. Stand where MLK delivered his "I Have A...


More  



I had not imagined the sheer size of the memorial. The presentation was truly something to slow down a and take in.

A great site on a sunny day. We recommend walking around the reflecting pool and taking it all in, early mornings or late afternoons to avoid heavy traffic. However the walkway is huge so don't be intimidated by large amounts of tourists.

Great views, free, and easy access. This piece of history is a must see for any American citizen!! Our most famous present is well displayed. At night it's even better!!

Stood in awe. The history from our 16th president is unbelievable. The huge Gettysburg Address to the left of the statue makes you aware of how important it was in American history. There is a small!! Gift shop here to get your passport stamped and to pick up small souvenirs and books. An elevator here as well for handicapped. Exhibits...


More  



This is really a place that is spectacular every time you visit. Incredible views, and the size and scope of it really does take your breath away. The reflecting pools are off for the winter but it was still worth the visit.

this area of dc is truly as beautiful as the movies make it out to be. the lincoln memorial is grand and iconic. a tribute to a wonderful president and definitely worth all the stairs one must climb to get there. turn around and face the washington monument, looking out over the reflecting pool, and picture jenny running through the...


More  



Awesome memorial to view a great president! The reflecting pool is empty right now, not sure why they drained it. You cannot only view the memorial here of Lincoln but can get awesome photos looking back towards the National mall with the Washington Monument in the backdrop. This is a must see while in DC.

The most beautiful monument in Washington DC. From here you will have nice view on World War II memorial, Washington monument and Capitol

title: National Gallery of Art, Washington DC
address: 6th Street and Constitution Avenue, Washington DC, DC 20002
review_list:
LOVE the building, LOVE the works of art- I just LOVE going here. Definitely a do not miss when visiting DC.
Make sure you take the underground walkway from the main museum to the modern art gallery across the street- very neat.

The National Gallery of Art has an excellent collection of Impressionist works as well as the only Leonardo da Vinci in the United States. The museum is well laid out, easy to navigate, and readily accessible for the disabled.

I also highly recommended their organised tours: the volunteers are knowledgeable and entertaining and it helps unlock interesting facts you probably wouldn't spot yourself

If you are nearby, which you are most likely to be then I would suggest a stop at the National Gallery. It is well laid out and has a nice mix of modern exhibits and portraits.

The building and its contents are very beautiful with classic art. Our docent was lovely and very patient with the group of children I was chaperoning on a field trip. In this trip and on others with just my family I've noticed some of the other workers can be a bit surly. It must be frustrating for them to have...


More  



If you can only see one museum on your visit to DC, this one is the one to see! Couples will love this (romantic and hip). Great for families with teens -- even with small children, this is very much worth a visit. Go on a tour, or create your own personal Art Scavenger Hunt! Don't feel you have to...


More  



My favorite part of this building is the spectacular art tunnel that connects the east and west wings.

We go to the National Gallery several times a year for special exhibits and to re-visit favorite collections. So much to see. Very strong Dutch and impressionist galleries. Stunning portraits of the first set of presidents. Simply a wonderful museum for all.

The National gallery of art is a haven for art lovers. There are original paintings from world famous masters and some very good remakes. The displays are period wise and is a good narration of how art progressed with human civization.

Quite why we were so surprised at the number of great works there are here I'm not sure. After all this is America's capital and their national gallery but room after room contained the sorts of treasures you read about in art history books. Leonardo, Titian, Rubens, Tintoretto, Vermeer, Van Gogh, Monet, Degas, Picasso, and of course the great American...

title: Smithsonian National Air and Space Museum, Washington DC
address: 6th and Independence Ave., SW, Washington DC, DC 20560
review_list:
This is a "guys" paradise. They have almost every type of flying machine known to man. Rockets, planes, jets, space craft, you name it. This is a two day museum. Eat before you go because dining options inside (McDonalds) are limited. Ladies, you will likely be bored.

Of course, this is a pretty great place. It's a bit overwhelming and the entrance is under construction which, frankly, gives you a bit of a bad first impression. But there's fun stuff, the kids love it, it's great to see some of these things. The stars are the space ships, the rest is actually pretty pedestrian stuff - although...


More  



There was so much to see here! We had an extra 90 minutes to do something, so decided to see what all we could know out here. The moon rock was my favorite.

Everyone loves this museum. I have been SO many times, maybe I'm just bored with it... but, I think it's badly in need of updating. There is some cool stuff there, so I would plan to walk through it, I just don't think it's as great as other people do. I did set up a field trip here once and...


More  



The airplanes in this museum are fantastic lots for anyone to see and there is also hands on stuff for kids to do

My preferred area was a room with the history of satellites and navigation before GPS. There are many instruments there.

Went here in January when we were told tourist activity was lowest... Well, not on a holiday weekend. Great exhibits and great for families, just be prepared to wait in long lines and practice patience if you pick a busy day.

I was a little disappointed - the museum had lots to read and some great large planes and shuttles but it took a lot of reading and didn't really grab you. There are a few hands on options throughout the day and they were fun.

Loved this place!!! Learnt so much about the history of aviation and the American space program. Visited on the weekend so quite busy but so worth it.

The National Air and Space Museum is a great place to visit with something to do for everyone. I have been before, and my little 10 year boy was the most excited to visit here and we could hardly get him out of here for all the exhibits. They have hands on exhibits for little ones and you can also...


More

title: United States Holocaust Memorial Museum, Washington DC
address: 100 Raoul Wallenberg Plaza SW, Washington DC, DC 20024
review_list:
This museum was very interesting and touching, to say the least. I learned a lot about the Holocaust, and still in disbelief. Very sobering, but well worth the time spent paying respects to those lost.

This was my first visit here. I could have easily stayed three hours. It was fascinating and emotional at the same time. Do not miss it.

A museum that can not be missed. The museum is for all ages. The 55 year old and over to remember what our grandparents spoke of. The 15 year old to live the history that should never happen again. You need 2.5 hours minimum really 4hours would be great. The day we went it was not busy so Im not...


More  



What can one say which has not already been said? Roughly 10 million people from dozens of countries perished in Nazi concentration camps, but it is estimated that a similar number died under the Soviets. What is unique about the US Holocaust Museum is the detailed explanation it provides for the rapid rise of the Nazi party and the virtually...


More  



You will head in to this museum with somber excitement and leave feeling depressed and angry. Obviously you know what you're getting yourself in to but be prepared to patiently wait through lines and read/look as tragedy unfolds as the museum leads you through the history of the holocaust and the intolerance of Hitler.

It was one of most interesting and sad experiences of my life. I believe everyone should visit this museum! Get there early so you can get in, it takes a while to see and read everything.

I really don't think I can add anything meaningful given the thousands of already great reviews. But I will say, after seeing long lines on a Saturday, we went at 10:30 on a Sunday morning to get behind the initial wave... perfect timing, we had no wait for the detectors.

The museum is free and effectively explains the rise of Hitler and the Nazis and the progression from harassment of Jews to the elimination of them and other people that the regime considered undesirable, including Poles, gypsies, mentally and physically impaired, gays, political opponents.
Especially powerful are the cards that you get going into the museum which briefly describe the...


More  



Very emotional and learned so much. Unbelievable, so sad but a life changing tour. I would recommend.

Arrive when they open. We were the 1st people into the museum and spent 3 hours there. When we came out, the line was literally around the buidling.

title: Library of Congress, Washington DC
address: 101 Independence Ave SE, Washington DC, DC 20540
review_list:
The building's interior is visually stunning. See a Guttenburg Bible. See letters written by George Washington, Thomas Jefferson and the like. Also on display are the contents of Abraham Lincoln's pockets from the evening he was assassinated. It's truly chilling!!!!!!!

This is one of my favorite buildings in DC, it's particularly beautiful at Christmas time. Make sure you visit all the exhibits downstairs, there is even a kids library down the end of a hallway... and you can take the underground walkway to the Capitol building.

The Library of Congress is the largest library in the world - and one of the four most visited sites in Washington. This place could be the most memorable places to see. The Jefferson Building is beautiful, the Madison building has an excellent cafeteria and the Adams building is an Art Deco Gem. Take a free tour or just walk...


More  



Short trip from the nation capital building tour. Beautiful ceiling inside. The Thomas Jefferson collection was impressive. The subject of books he collected was very interesting. They did have a kids activity booklet they can do, for younger kids. There is a gift shop to get a patch and souvenirs. They did have bottled water here, not cold.
The Guttenberg...


More  



Wonderful architecture, many interesting details. In the library you can find Jefferson's books and Gutenberg Bible, they have copy of every book thst is issued in the US.

The inside of this building is breathtaking! The architecture, the statues, and Thomas Jefferson's library. Also, it is connected to the Capital if you are going over there for a tour.

The Library of Congress is spectacular in what it represents and the architecture. When visiting, don't forget Madison Hall and the stunning statue of James Madison, Father of the Constitution.

Just the most beautiful building. We visited here directly from the The Capitol Building tour . You can walk here via underground tunnels that contain interesting posters and displays on the way through .
The Library itself is spectacular. The Ceilings and Windows are just magnificent as is are the displays and side galleries. A must see for history buffs

This superb library takes one's breath away - and that's before you get to the books and exhibitions. Look at the pics on Google images - than go there! Good shop, pleasant and helpful staff.

It's a must see, don't think if it as just another Library, but as a one of the great Art and Architecture buildings ever built!

title: Newseum, Washington DC

While I wouldn't visit here over some of the Smithsonian Museums, if you're looking for something different and very interesting, this was a couple of well spent hours. Great history of the role the news has played in the past 300+ years.

More  



Easy to get lost here for hours amongthe wonderful exhibits! Each time I am in DC I come back and see more and more than I missed the first time!

You can park in the Newseum's garage - I paid $20 for the entire day. There were 6 floors and some very thought-provoking multimedia exhibits. Well worth it!

One of the only pay entry museums but definately worth a visit. Your ticket is good for two days also. There are some really thought provoking exhibits like Vietnam war, equality etc.

My wife and I spent hours here last summer. This "museum" is 7 floors of nothing but incredible artifacts and news items. This is an attraction where you have to pay to get in but the pass is good for two days and you can easily get your money's worth. I especially enjoyed the Berlin wall exhibit and the news...

Took a group of 30 school students here as part of a recent trip to Washington DC. Museum was fascinating and very interactive. The exhibition of Vietnam was reporting and Pulitzer photograph exhibition were superb. Would highly recommend!

This is the best place to visit in Washington DC! Do not miss it! The tickets are good for two days and you will definitely need to come back. In fact I probably could have spent a week just in this one museum, and I am one of those who usually covers a museum in an hour and think that...

We love the Newseum! This was our second visit and we still love it. It can be hard to pay for a museum in a city filled with free museums, but its worth it.
It is history museum as seen through the eyes of the journalist who report it! Great permanent exhibits, like the Berlin Wall and 9/11. And probably...

title: Vietnam Veterans Memorial, Washington DC
address: 5 Henry Bacon Dr NW, Washington DC, DC 20242
review_list:
Easy to get to, right by the Lincoln Memorial.... very somber and poignant. Always clean and well kept...

Take the time to stroll slowly along the wall and appreciate all the names that adorn it. These brave men and women gave all to their country and a thank you should be the least we mutter as we pass.

This place commands respect and is tastefully done. The thousands of names are put into perspective by the design of the walls. Pay your respects and visit this place!!! You owe it to those who sacrifices for us!!

Very moving. Brought my 12 year old son. He was in awe of the number of lives lost. Start at the smaller end and make your way down. Divided into years if you're looking for a relative. We collect patches. We found one for here in the Lincoln memorial gift shop.

This is not perhaps one of the most 'popular' memorials - no great soaring white marble statues here - but it is incredibly moving and poignant. Marble walls which are, sadly, far far too long, all of which with names of those who died either in the conflict or after/because of it. There is a book in a glass case...


More  



I have always seen pictures on tv but pictures don't come close to how overwhelming the experience of seeing all the american soldiers names in person on the wall. This is something everyone should see at some point in their life.

This brings tears to your eyes just seeing all those names. There are books there that you can look up the individuals and it indicates exactly where you can find that special persons name on the wall. This is a must see for every one.

Have attended this Memorial Wall on several occasions, as a matter of fact, every time I come to Washington. It is a tribute to those who lost their lives in this war. Their names are listed on the wall. It includes Canadians also as well as other nationalities. Very impressive and worth the visit. If you're walking, it's just a...


More  



This is a must see when in Washington DC. It really is a moving tribute to all those that fought and lost their lives in the War

It was my first time visiting this memorial and I was completely overwhelmed by seeing how many lives lost are represented. Speechless.

title: Korean War Veterans Memorial, Washington DC
address: 10 Daniel French Dr SW, Washington DC, DC 20001
review_list:
The statues are life size, so it's very cool/lifelike at night- even more so in the snow. There is lots of symbolism in the way the Memorial is built, so either look it up before you go or take a Ranger led tour that explains everything.

I was very impressed by the setting of the soldiers that seemed to come alive as the platoon walked every so cautions in formation. The life like features and attention to detail were inspiring.

Stunning memorial. Emotional. Best to hear the background of how this memorial was constructed with a guide (or do your research beforehand).

This memorial is tucked to the side of the National Mall area near the Lincoln Memorial. It is well done and worth the travel over there to view the memorial for the Korean War. I do not think it is as neat as the Vietnam memorial, but still very cool and worth visiting.

Walking through the pouring rain approaching the Korean War Memorial, one gets the feeling you are one of the soldiers trudging through the mire trying desperately to stay alive. The life sized white washed statues grimacing painfully in the dank weather just brings it so to home. These young men gave up their lives.
The reflection pool with its quiet...


More  



I wasn't sure what to expect when I came to this memorial, but this wasn't it. The memorial itself is moving and the faces of the soldiers really rather haunting - but perhaps that is the whole point? It is the wall opposite the statues which is amazing. Each of the faces in the reflective marble are so lifelike they...


More  



I never expected to be so moved by this monument as much as I was. It is eerie, in a good way, at night as it gives you a sense of the fear these warriors felt while marching through the fields. It's great during the day as well but I prefer the night.

This is another great war memorial to visit while touring the others. The statues of Korean War veterans are haunting, especially in combination with the photos of veterans engraved in the wall.

An awe inspiring tribute. Walk around the entire exhibit, slowly. as you look back at the soldiers, notice that no matter where you are, there is always 1 soldier looking directly at you. Inspired by the fact that they were always watching out for one another.

Not as well recognized as the Vietnam Memorial but I give it 2 thumbs up as a tribute to all those who served and paid the ultimate sacrifice.

title: National World War II Memorial, Washington DC
address: 17th Street NW, between Constitution and Independence Avenues, Washington DC, DC 20006
review_list:
I enjoyed taking our group here a dusk. We found our state column and took a photo beside it. It is a beautiful monument.

This Memorial, like all the others, is beautiful. My favorite time to be there is at dusk/sunset- I imagine it would be equally lovely at sunrise.

The representation of both the Atlantic and Pacific fleets was an inspiring vision of tribute. The attention to detail and overall size was of fitting to our country that joined as many to defend as one.

My favorite Memorial. This gigantic piece of art and history ties together the National Mall and the Lincoln Memorial. Great spot for sightseers to start and pick a direction to travel to the next site,

The memorial has statues with wreath for each state. With a reflecting pool in the middle. There is a program for WWI vets to come and see this tribute honoring them. Glad we can honor these patriotic vets. Be sure to find your home state for a nice picture opp.

We had waited many years to visited this beautiful memorial to all those who served in World War II and we were not disappointed. Great memorial for one of the worst War's in our country's history. I was disappointed to see the water was drained, not sure why it's not there but it's much better when the fountains are going. My kids loved running over and finding the different states and learning about the War. A must visit for anyone traveling through the National...

We visited in February when, unfortunately, all the pools and fountains etc are drained (as it gets very, very cold in Washington). This memorial was very impressive but I should imagine that when the water is in the reflective pool, it would be magnificent. The intricate carvings at the tops of the memorials of Pacific and Atlantic are artistic, and...

My wife and I visited Washington and planned on visiting all the sites and had a few walking tours booked with "Tours for Humanity" and on the first tour we visited the World War 2 Memorial. The WWII memorial lies in the shadow of TWO revered monuments - the Lincoln Memorial AND the Washington Monument. You can stand at the WWII monument and see both. Stand in awe, if you will.

review_list:
Pretty cool that it had all of the four sections for each of his terms. It was raining though, so we had to hurry through it.

I absolutely *love* this Memorial! The sound of the water crashing down adds to the great atmosphere, and there is SO much symbolism in the Memorial itself. Try to take one of the Ranger led tours, to learn about all the symbolism. This Memorial, like the rest, is gorgeous at night... and one of my favorite spots for looking at...

This is a very different memorial than the others. It's like an outdoor museum. Lots of parking nearby on the tidal basin. The memorial is both inspirational and educational

Was on our tour for the day. They do have a gift shop where you get your passport stamped. Most shops here don't have extra paper in case you forget your passport. Bring a pad with you from your hotel.
The statues throughout the memorial was very appropriate. The soup kitchen was our favorite.

The FDR memorial is located on the Tidal Basin across from the Jefferson Memorial. It's very large and is divided by the FRD's three terms. There is lots of granite and many fountains and large bronze statues. This lovely space is especially nice in warm weather, but can be depressing on cold rainy days.

This memorial is easy to get to and PARK at night…..its very safe at night also because there are lots of park police. The stone displays portray the realness of the people that suffered through the depression - and of course celebrated the largeness and expanse of the Roosevelt years.

Most of us locals will tell you the FDR is among our favorite of the memorials around the mall. Inspired design, gorgeous setting, and not usually overly crowded. A must see.

Why is there so much space devoted to this President? So many important events in American history, so many facets of our presidents to depict, yet only so much land. How to decide? One of the largest memorials in DC. It's not on the Mall but is very close to the Jefferson memorial. I really liked the statue of President Roosevelt's dog. I love this outside memorial to FDR and his legacy. This memorial is gorgeous. I'm not a huge fan of Thomas Jefferson considering he was a slave owner, however as a founding father of this country, I paid my respect. The architecture is awesome.

This is my favorite Washington, DC memorial. I love the fact that the architecture of the memorial reflects the architectural style of Jefferson's Monticello. Good Memorial, peaceful... has bathrooms underneath, which is nice... my favorite time to visit this Memorial is later at night, when there aren't many people... or when there ARE a lot of people, and they sit out on the steps socializing... makes for a nice atmosphere either way.

Once again the overall size is a sight to see to believe. Take the time to look up and appreciate the detail.

Include this place in your memorial tour. The view is amazing and you can take good pics. It won't take a lot to enjoy this places and see the amazing Jefferson sculpture inside.

The statue itself was a shock as to how big it really is. The tv and books don't do it justice. The book store and little exhibts are down stairs. There in an elevator for handicapped. You get your passport stamped here.

This is one of my favorite monuments in DC! After climbing the stairs in the front, the inside of the monument is beautiful. A good sight seeing place to stop at and check out in DC. What is also nice about this monument is it is not as crowded as some of the other stops in DC and there is...

Across the wading pool is a lonely memorial to Thomas Jefferson. Like the Lincoln Memorial, it pays tribute to a great man in US History. Difficult to get to because you can take a wrong exit and end up on the other side of the lake. Some better signage would help

The Jefferson Memorial is a little out of the way but is worth the time to get here and enjoy, it is not as full as the Lincoln but shares just as much historical significance. We had a better time here due to less crowds.

Inspiring place to stand and look out at the water. We went here on our 8th grade field trip and it was pretty inspiring.

title: Washington National Cathedral, Washington DC

This place always reminds me of the Cathedrals I saw in Europe, it's so beautiful! Make sure you go downstairs to see everything down there, and up to the observation level. The gardens are pretty in the spring. They have a tour and tea that is really neat.

I remember so well the civil rights movements and its many leaders, chief among them Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr. A trip to Washington D.C. was coming up and I made a commitment that I would make time to visit the MLK memorial. I am glad that I did.

A magnificent memorial to an amazing man . The way this is been done provides the Visitor with an overview of Kings famous comments & allows you to gain some understanding of the struggle of the African Americans that he became the reluctant leader off .

My parents and I took a nighttime bus tour of the monuments and this is the one I remember the best. It was an absolutely fantastic memory. So beautiful. So moving. If you see anything, make sure you see this monument and take time to read every quote and spend some time in quiet contemplation.

A must-see when visiting all of the National Memorials on the Mall. A little off to the side, but right on the river which is really very beautiful. Especially at night.

Beautifully restored historic theater with an amazing museum in same building. Reasonably priced for outstanding regional theater. A very professional presentation of the Glass Menagerie! Excellent acting in a beautiful theater. A must go to attraction.

It is sad to know that President Lincoln was shot here-And that he died in the house right across the street. Yet, you have to see it. How theaters were back then and where the awful thing took place. It IS a beautiful theater though. Still in use. Well worth seeing!

They have live music (small) concerts that are listed on their website. I wish I had know earlier because they had a great one planned that evening but tickets were sold out.

We really enjoyed the multiple collections and the settings of the Phillips Collection. Staff are friendly and there is plenty of space to take your time and contemplatively enjoy the moment. Reasonably priced admission. There are plenty of food and beverage choices in the surrounding areas for a nice time after as well.

The Phillips permanent collection is not large, but it is a place to visit for its special exhibits, which they do very well. Look for them as they can be spectacular. At the most recent one we viewed several exceptional works, including a Van Gogh that was extraordinary.

The Phillip Collection as a private collection it's like a sneak peek on someone's door. The saloons are now a gallery full of well-known artists, Miro e Monet, long halls and rooms with beautiful paintings and sculptures. The garden is perfect for a sunny day.

The Phillips gallery is a lovely collection of art in a beautiful architectural setting. Just spending time with Renoir's: Dejeuner des Canotiers is worth the stop.

I adore the Phillips Collection. Though you do have to pay a bit for it, unlike the Smithsonians, it is completely worth it. Gorgeous old DC houses converted into an even better museum. title: Vietnam Women's Memorial, Washington DC

review_list:

Beautiful, old canals and locks, stone buildings, and really well done plaques telling you who lived their in the early yerars. Right in the midst of modern Georgetown

title: President Lincoln's Cottage, Washington DC
address: 140 Rock Creek Church Road NW and Upshur Street, NW, Washington DC, DC 20011-8400
review_list:
President Lincoln's Cottage is not far from the White House, and is well-staffed with knowledgeable guides. Our guide, Don, conducted a tour of the house, sharing additional anecdotes and commentary to the videos, pictures, quotations, and recordings that made up the core of the tour.
The cottage is sparsely furnished to stay true to what it was like when the...


More  



Found it almost by mistake and pleased that I took the time to visit the site, learn a bit more of Washington history, and saw a wonderful exhibit on human trafficking. If you're in the area or a civil war buff, worth the time. Takes less than a hour to complete the tour.

We visited Pres. Lincoln's Cottage on President's weekend--how fitting. Only open since 2000. The restoration was done to perfection. The guided tour was fabulous and filled with interesting facts about the great deal of time that Pres Lincoln spent at this residence. Well worth the trip.

Took my Dad and my boyfriend here... Let me say that is was incredible. The tour is only an hour but the story telling from the tour guide brings it alive and gives a profound perspective of a President who took us through the Civil War.
I really really enjoyed this tour, so much that I would do it again.

Very pleasant, almost real-life experience of this part of the history of the Unite States in a very personal way. Friendly and knowledgeable staff.

Just three miles from the White House is one of Washington's little known gems: President Abraham Lincoln's "cottage." Located on the grounds of a home for retired and disabled soldiers dating to the 1850's, this was a retreat for Lincoln and his family during the Civil War. Rob was a terrific guide--passionate and informative. A little tricky to find so...

We visited the site on a recent weekday. I needed my GPS to find it (make sure you read the website to get the CORRECT address), but parking was easy when we arrived. The welcome center is very well set up, with videos and exhibits.

Our book club visited here during a 3-day annual trip to DC. We all agreed that it was an outstanding experience. Rob was a passionate and knowledgeable guide who happily spent a lot of time talking to us. For all Lincoln Learners, this place is a must-see!

I need to politely say I wouldn't do this again. I'd recommend The Ford's Theater.
The tour just wasn't worth the money, nor the time.

title: Hirshhorn Museum and Sculpture Garden, Washington DC
address: Independence Ave. SW, Smithsonian Institutions, Washington DC, DC 20560
review_list:
It's a great museum if you love modern art. There are some really fascinating pieces. I'm a bit more traditional in my art tastes so I'm not as crazy about this museum. It's not that large a museum compared to others in the area. For me this works out well. Just about the time I run out of patience with...


More  



Visited the museum to view the special exhibition on Surrealist Sculptures. Wonderful.
Few people were there. Maybe it's the subject matter or the bad weather we've been having might have affected the attendance.
Thought the painting on the walls, ceiling, and floors of the museum was a bit unreal (shown in photos attached). Need decorating ideas?

The permanent collection concentrates on 20th century modernism and is as impressive as any in the city. Rotating exhibitions address historical retrospectives and more contemporary works.

We haven't visited in a while and loved returning. Today we spent all o f our time in the surrealism exhibit. Learned a lot and did not realize the Cornell boxes were in that category. Nice place. When we went in years past our children loved looking at the sculptures and all. It is always a favorite.

Interesting building with some nice sculptures surrounding it. The exhibitions and rooms are well put together though it's a shame you can hardly take any photos. I loved looking at the original Dali's, Man Ray's and Rene Magritte's. The surrealism section was definitely the best I thought and had some great interactive bits including a massive wall with lots of...


More  



Very neat museum! We only had an hour and a half to visit, but so happy we stopped in! If you love modern art this is a must. If modern art isn't your thing, its still pretty interesting. The gardens were really nice too.

This is a bit like an art college at the end of the year after the students have taken all the good pieces back home! There are some good 'heavier' pieces in the sculpture garden which they couldn't quite manage. My advice would be to turn this into an art college. It might add a bit of life to the...


More  



Like visiting some old friends in the art world. Love the permanent collection. Temporary exhibitions are hit or miss. Washington DC museums are always free - what's not to like!

The museum itself is a lovely round building with interesting sculptures outside. The collection is well curated and a very manageable size. The staff was very helpful. This is a small great museum that you can add on to a visit at any of the larger museums at the Smithsonion.

The Hirshhorn is always wonderful, but their special exhibit on Surrealism was truly special. Whimsical pieces by Calder (check out the fish!), surprising insights into the politics, exhibits, and community of surrealist artists in Paris in the 1930's, and evocative pieces by many lesser known artists. Well worth a two-hour visit or more.

title: White House Visitors Center, Washington DC

title: National Museum of Women in the Arts, Washington DC
address: 1250 New York Avenue NW, Washington DC, DC 20005
review_list:
The special exhibits and the permanent exhibitions are always well presented and interesting for older (20+) visitors. Not a children's venue. Look for their schedule and enjoy the luncheon that is cheap and wonderful to be surrounded by great art.

The architecture is worth a visit itself....marble everywhere....beautiful staircase....many details and fine touches throughout the building. Small café is available on the 2nd floor .... serves soup, sandwiches etc on a limited basis, supplied by Union Kitchen, which was very good..

Pleasantly surprised to find this museum is open to all free of charge on the first Sunday of the month. The exhibit PATHMAKERS was a delightful mix of art, design, and crafts by women of the world. I also thoroughly enjoy the file on Eva Zeisel which was 1 hour in length. The staff was marvelous and very helpful.

We just happened to catch this museum on their one free day a month – the first Sunday of every month. That certainly was a bonus for us. The museum is housed in a former Masonic Temple and has been opened since 1987. This museum is dedicated strictly to women artists – such a nice change. The ground floor still...


More  



We loved the permanent collections as well as the temporary works of art that were there. I highly recommend this museum to everyone. Will definitely go back!

We attended a wedding at the Museum of Women in the Arts. Absolutely stunning. It's a beautiful building.

Simply gorgeous. Cocktail hour amongst priceless works of art. Dinner and dancing were on separate floors, but it didn't seem to have an impact. One of the most beautiful wedding venues I have been to.

Tough this museum is not a part of the Smithsonian and therefore you have to pay entry, I found it to be worthwhile. The art was well curated and, in part, quite well known. I would definitely suggest not overlooking this smaller museum in downtown DC.

There's nothing much here to see. It's an embarrassment to women in the arts. Perhaps if they have a major exhibit it may be worth your time and money. Otherwise, skip it! You will see much better examples of the best artists for free at the National Gallery.

Attended a function at this museum for the holidays and was very impressed. Beautiful museum, wonderful location for a corporate function.

title: National Japanese American Memorial, Washington DC
